A Mom, Wife, Daughter, Sister 
and extremely Carefree Individual. 
i love watching TV series, movies, cooking shows, documentaries, news, anything would do. 
I'm interested in almost everything, so you might end up seeing anything on my dash. I'm a JONSA(jon/sansa) shipper. I'm a firm supporter of "SHIP AND LET SHIP" and "LET'S AGREE TO DISAGREE"
I have no problem with people who ship them with others or who are multi shippers. But be warned that I post a lot of Jonsa content. O and I dislike Daenerys Targaryen(can't stand all the burning stuff up and the entitlement) So don't follow if you don't agree.
My OTHER favorite shows and otps are Jamestown, Merlin, Grimm, SilverMadi (BlackSails) Klayley (The Originals), Olicity (Arrow), Darvey (Suits) and Kennash(Reign, this ship broke my heart, my headcanon is that he is alive and ends up with her where ever she is)

summary:
I just got called a Delusional Sansa Stan! 
I don't know what's more hilarious, That these antis only have one word for all fans...
body:
I just got called a Delusional Sansa Stan!

I don’t know what’s more hilarious, That these antis only have one word for all fans who disagree with them or that they truly believe this word triggers us.

Every time I see it I burst out laughing.

title: Whumptober Day 4
body:
Prompt: “No, stop!”
Fandom: Game of Thrones
Characters: Sansa Stark, Ramsay Bolton
Word Count: 302
Trigger warnings: referenced rape/non-con, physical abuse, psychological abuse

She makes the mistake of begging only once.

“No, stop! Please!” she chokes, barely able to get the word past the bile in her throat, but she does her best to hold in the tears that want to come out, to hold back the panic clawing at the inside of her chest.

She can make him happy. She knows she can. Joffrey had liked it ever so much when she cried out in pain. He said it reminded him of singing, and she’d always had the loveliest voice. Caged birds always did.

She doesn’t know what her newest husband likes, aside from hurting her. But she can find out. She can beg, and cry, and make all the right noises until he’s satisfied with his prize.

Ramsay listens, stops, smiles, and she doesn’t dare to smile back. Joffrey hadn’t let her enjoy any moment of happiness for long; if they are not the same monster, then they are similar enough for it to be true of him, too.

He reaches for her face, and she fights the shudder traveling down her spine. Would showing more fear make it worse? It can’t possibly make this better.

His fingers clamp like a vice around her cheeks, squishing them in his hand like Mother once did to Arya when she was being obstinate, only she has a feeling his grip is much crueler than their lady Mother ever was; she can feel the bruises forming already.

Ramsay Bolton’s face is horribly pleasant as he scolds her, “I don’t take well to orders, lady wife.”

She only has a moment to comprehend his words before the whip comes out.

She can barely walk for several days afterward, and only then with Reek’s assistance.

She makes the mistake of begging only once.

She doesn’t try it again.

tags: tamra from RHOOC voice 'THATS MY OPINIOOONNN'
question: auburn, winterfell and dagger!
answer:
4. auburn: do you like Sansa’s character? explain why you do/don’t


I love her character. LET ME COUNT THE WAYS. Like it could go on a long time. Firstly, since I started with the show, she was just clearly the pretty, young feminine princess type character..which is just like, boom, ok, that one, that one is my favourite. Every show I watch, I’ve always liked the real GIRL girl character. When i was 8 watching scooby doo, it was daphne over velma, 10 and watching digimon, I’d like mimi over sora, when I was watching beyblade, i liked mariah more than….i actually cant remember another female character in that show but whatever. Now even as an adult, I’m still the same. I love prettiness and girliness and all that. I also love bratty/spoilt sweet characters. I’ve always said Sansa is like the cher horowitz of westoros and I stand by that statement. Getting a little bit more deep, I also love how her story is a kind of deconstruction of a story a ‘princess’ type character is meant to have. In that it all goes so horribly wrong, genuinely. In real life, historically, princesses are more like chess pieces on a board and they have to navigate some very hostile environments while being placed on a pedestal and having very little say in what their lives will be (like marie antoinette or anne boleyn, ladies who I was really fascinated by when I was in highschool and reading a whole tonne of historic fiction) and I LOVE how GRRM has written this so well with Sansa. I love her thoughts and fears and you can feel her naivety but also the sense of her learning and how she adapts. I love how subtly she’s shaped over her chapters. By cersei and joffrey and kings landing, all the way to the vale with baelish. I love the whole vibe of such a ‘perfect princess’ character slowly descending into politics and scheming whilst maintaining the facade. God, i’ve got to stop this is already a wall of text yall dont want to read TLDR I love sansa hard.

12. winterfell: do you think sansa will get back to her Stark roots by the end of the book saga? Or will she completely detach from her family and become more alayne-ish?

I think she’s developed into her own person ,and will eventually be very much removed from traditional ‘stark’ values. Just because even at the beginning of the story, her main influence was Catelyn, whereas the other siblings, even arya, seem closer/more influenced by Ned, who is more..Starky. Through all Sansa been through and what she’s learned through her experiences alone in very formative years, I don’t think she’ll value honour and honesty in the same way. I don’t think she’ll see the best in people. Lying has been her most valuable asset. I’m also one of the people who think Lady dying is very symbolic and foreshadowing of her detachment from her ‘starkness’ no matter how hard some people think its irrelevant. Throughout sansa’s chapters theres so much bird imagery, the hound calling her little bird, wishing she could fly away, petyr’s crest for house baelish which she resides under in later chapters as his ‘daughter’, while the OTHER stark kids are ALL wolves all the time in their chapters (and no i dont think sansa will warg into a bird, I think she’s cut off from any warging ability she may have been able to have when lady died. again, the presence and hints or warging in all the other kids chapters, while its absent in sansa’s, always struck me as a clear difference between them). Also, as i say this, I don’t mean to say she doesn’t love her family or that they don’t love her or that she doesnt love winterfell, because she clearly does. I just see her themes, personality, values, and everything is REALLY seperate from the other Stark kids.

14. dagger: a character you’d like to see interacting with petyr

I would have liked to have seen the pre book one small council in kings landing, with stannis and Petyr having to interact with each other. With renly and bobby B being themselves in the mix, and varys. It’d be like Stannis trying to manage an unruly classroom, popping panadol for his oncoming tension headaches.

With renly and bobby B being themselves in the mix, and varys. It’d be like Stannis trying to manage an unruly classroom, popping panadol for his oncoming tension headaches.

summary: About Sansa, Jon, and apples Part I
title: About Sansa, Jon, and apples Part I
body:
I saw people posting about Sansa’s name and what it means on Tumblr yesterday and decided to post this bit about Sansa and apples and her connection to Jon. There could very well be more than one inspiration behind Sansa’s name but there exists a Sansa apple, which I have heard kind of tastes like Royal Gala apples, but I have never eaten one, so cannot tell (never seen one here in England either).

Plus it is apple-picking season, so why not!!!

Anyways, talking about apples, reminded me of this picture from that old Time magazine photo shoot that some of the GOT cast did a while back.

Here is Sophie Turner with a green apple (and she appears to have taken a bite off) in her hand and while others in the fandom have dissected the many meanings of this, here is what I found while I was re-reading A Storm of Swords. (if others have also talked about this, then oh well, another drop of water to the ocean and all that then) Part I will talk about Sansa’s connections to apples and Part II will feature Jon’s connections to apples. This post got longer than I planned.

There were three Tyrell cousins, Megga and Alla and Elinor, all close to Sansa’s age. Buxom Lady Janna was Lord Tyrell’s sister, and wed to one of the green-apple Fossoways; dainty, bright-eyed Lady Leonette was a Fossoway as well, and wed to Ser Garlan. Septa Nysterica had a homely pox-scarred face but seemed jolly. Pale, elegant Lady Graceford was with child, and Lady Bulwer was a child, no more than eight.

-Sansa I, ASOS

House Fossoway, sworn to House Tyrell, has two branches, the red apple Fossoways, and the green apple Fossoways. This Lady Janna is married to Ser Jon Fossoway, who is called Ser Jon of the green apple.

So Sansa is eating a green apple and there exists a Ser Jon of the green apple???!!! Are you kidding me!

In fact, this Ser Jon of the green apple first makes his appearance in a Sansa chapter!

“the freerider Lothor Brune, who’d cut his way through half a hundred Fossoway men-at-arms to capture Ser Jon of the green apple and kill Ser Bryan and Ser Edwyd of the red, thereby winning himself the name Lothor Apple-Eater.”

-Sansa VIII, ACOK

(This Lothor Brune is a free-rider, employed under Petyr Baelish and is connected to Sansa too. He once saved Sansa from the groping hands of Marillion, when she was in the Eyrie, that happens later in ASOS.)

Dainty and bright-eyed Lady Leonette is married to Ser Garlan Tyrell, who is called The Gallant and is a nod to Jon Snow. @shinynewrevulsions has written a meta on Jon Snow and Garlan Tyrell parallels.

Lady Leonette belongs to which branch of House Fossoway is unknown. So she could be a green apple Fossoway or a red apple Fossoway.

Pale and elegant Lady Graceford’s full name is Lady Alyce Graceford and she is pregnant. Alyce sounds like Alys, which reminds me of Alys Karstark, who is a Sansa stand-in. 

(Someone in the fandom wrote a meta on Sansa/Alys Karstark parallels, but I cannot find it. However, there is plenty of parallels between the two.)

Lady Graceford is described to be pale and elegant, words that are often used to describe Sansa.

This Lady Alyce Graceford shows up again later in ASOS…during Joffrey’s wedding. Tyrion and Sansa are sitting next to Ser Garlan Tyrell and Lady Leonette Fossoway at Joffrey’s wedding and Tyrion wonders this about Sansa…

“Does she wish it were her in Margaery’s place?” Tyrion frowned. Even a child should have better sense. He turned away, wanting distraction, but everywhere he looked were women, fair fine beautiful happy women who belonged to other men.”

-Tyrion VIII, ASOS

I think, “Everywhere he looked were women” also includes the woman sitting next to Tyrion, Sansa, who despite being married to him, belongs to someone else (IDK Jon??). 

“And there was one woman, sitting almost at the foot of the third table on the left…the wife of one of the Fossoways, he thought, and heavy with his child. Her delicate beauty was in no way diminished by her belly, nor was her pleasure in the food and frolics. Tyrion watched as her husband fed her morsels off his plate. They drank from the same cup, and would kiss often and unpredictably. Whenever they did, his hand would gently rest upon her stomach, a tender and protective gesture.”

-Tyrion VIII, ASOS

Sitting almost at the foot of the table reminds me of how Jon was made to sit at the lower benches in the Great Hall of Winterfell during the welcome feast for King Robert Baratheon. The third table may be alluding to Jon being the third child of Rhaegar. Sitting on the left side to Joffrey who is king and newly married so gets the highest seat of honor, also denotes the place where the queen resides. Joffrey is a foil to Jon. So this Lady sitting to Joffrey’s left denotes where Sansa might be sitting when she marries King Jon. (Tyrion and Sansa were sitting to Joffrey’s right)

This pregnant woman is married to one of the Fossoways, does not say whether it is a green apple Fossoway or red apple Fossoway. She is seated close to the Tyrells, Margaery’s cousins are sitting nearby. So I think, this pregnant lady is possibly the same Lady Alyce Graceford that we meet in Sansa I ASOS, considering the people she hangs out with are the same in both chapters. Her beauty in Tyrion VIII ASOS is described to be delicate, and kind of sounds similar to elegant and beautiful, all things that aptly describe Sansa.

But think how sweet and romantic this pair is, where the husband is feeding her morsels off his plate and they are drinking from the same cup…huh where have we seen that before????

YUP!! When they reunite in S0604 in Castle Black!! Oh apologies, did I mean Jon and Sansa??? Oops, I guess I did. 

Sharing a drink is a very common wedding tradition in many cultures. The Scottish have the wedding Quaich ceremony where couples drink from a double-handed cup. I am sure other cultures have similar things but yeah sharing a drink is such a married people trope!

Plus I can totally imagine Jon doing all those things to a pregnant Sansa. 

Anyways back to Sansa I ASOS chapter, because there is more..

The song the Bear and the Maiden Fair is first sung in this chapter. Sansa and Jon are the Maiden and Bear in the song.

Following this Sansa chapter is Jon I, ASOS and here is what we find…

This is the chapter where Jon has been captured by the wildlings and taken to meet with Mance Rayder, the King beyond the Wall…here is how his tent is described.

There was no doubting which tent was the king’s. It was thrice the size of the next largest he’d seen, and he could hear music drifting from within. Like many of the lesser tents, it was made of sewn hides with the fur still on, but Mance Rayder’s hides were the shaggy white pelts of snow bears.

Jon I, ASOS

Jon Snow is the snow bear and the rightful King of the 7Ks. (It is known.lol)

In this tent is “a pregnant woman stood over a brazier cooking a brace of hens”.

“The good woman at the brazier,” Mance Rayder went on, “is Dalla.” The pregnant woman smiled shyly. “Treat her like you would any queen, she is carrying my child.”

So pregnant Lady Alyce Graceford, who appears to be a Sansa stand-in, from Sansa I, ASOS, and is married to one of the apple Fossoways, mirrors the shy Dalla, who is pregnant with a King’s child and ought to be treated like a queen in Jon I ASOS. Lady Graceford also sits on the left of King Joffrey, who is a Jon foil, in Tyrion VIII, ASOS, the place usually occupied by the queen.

I like this subtext very much.

Also, Mance Rayder’s physical description also has echoes of Jon’s physique in it.

“The King-beyond-the-Wall looked nothing like a king, nor even much a wildling. He was of middling height, slender, sharp-faced, with shrewd brown eyes and long brown hair that had gone mostly to grey. There was no crown on his head, no gold rings on his arms, no jewels at his throat, not even a gleam of silver. He wore wool and leather, and his only garment of note was his ragged black wool cloak, its long tears patched with faded red silk.”

-Jon I, ASOS

Jon is of middling height, slender and graceful and quick with eyes that hardly miss a thing. The black wool cloak patched with faded red silk is an obvious nod to the red and black colors of House Targaryen and thus to Jon. Hair gone mostly to grey is a node to the grey colors of House Stark. Again a nod to Jon, who is of the House Stark. The Black also denotes Jon and him being the black bastard of the Wall as part of the Night’s Watch. The “nor even much a wildling” may allude to Jon trying to infiltrate the wildlings and pretending to become a wildling in the process. However, he neither looks like one nor does he ends up becoming one.

Since all is subtext, I think this right here is actually meant to describe Jon and not Mance. The title of the King-beyond-the-Wall is such a clever way of calling Jon, the King, because if you think about it, when you are actually in the far North, past the Wall, and you are looking south, anything South of the Wall, can also be described as beyond the wall. And who is the rightful King of this side (Southern side) of the wall? Jon Snow of Houses Targaryen and Stark. 

Moving on, in this Jon I ASOS chapter, we first get to listen to the song The Dornishman’s Wife, and that is being sung by “a grey-haired man in a tattered cloak of black and red sat cross-legged on a pillow, playing a lute and singing..”

The grey-haired man in a cloak of black and red is another nod to Jon of the Houses Stark and Targaryen, who is also a Dornishman. A Dornishman’s wife can also be called a Dornishwoman. In fact, one of the only two times the word “Dornishwoman” shows up in the text in a POV chapter in ASOIAF, is in a Sansa chapter, Sansa IV, ASOS, talking about Ellaria Sand, paramour to the Red Viper of Dorne, Prince Oberyn. The other time is in the epilogue of ADWD.

Anyways, I think, there exists many subtextual clues that connect Jon and Sansa via apples or rather House Fossoway and may foreshadow them marrying and becoming King and Queen of the 7Ks and having a baby (or babies)!!! Here’s to at least some of that in S8!

(I am a quarter way through ASOS, and hopefully, if I can find any more apple connections, I will add on to this post. If others find some, would love to read about them. One thing that always strikes me is the sheer number of parallels that exist between Sansa I and Jon I chapters in ASOS, later chapters of these two also have quite a lot of clues).

So I think, this pregnant lady is possibly the same Lady Alyce Graceford that we meet in Sansa I ASOS, considering the people she hangs out with are the same in both chapters. Her beauty in Tyrion VIII ASOS is described to be delicate, and kind of sounds similar to elegant and beautiful, all things that aptly describe Sansa.

But think how sweet and romantic this pair is, where the husband is feeding her morsels off his plate and they are drinking from the same cup…huh where have we seen that before????

YUP!! When they reunite in S0604 in Castle Black!! Oh apologies, did I mean Jon and Sansa??? Oops, I guess I did. 

Sharing a drink is a very common wedding tradition in many cultures. The Scottish have the wedding Quaich ceremony where couples drink from a double-handed cup. I am sure other cultures have similar things but yeah sharing a drink is such a married people trope!

Plus I can totally imagine Jon doing all those things to a pregnant Sansa. 

Anyways back to Sansa I ASOS chapter, because there is more..

The song the Bear and the Maiden Fair is first sung in this chapter. Sansa and Jon are the Maiden and Bear in the song.

Following this Sansa chapter is Jon I, ASOS and here is what we find…

This is the chapter where Jon has been captured by the wildlings and taken to meet with Mance Rayder, the King beyond the Wall…here is how his tent is described.

There was no doubting which tent was the king’s. It was thrice the size of the next largest he’d seen, and he could hear music drifting from within. Like many of the lesser tents, it was made of sewn hides with the fur still on, but Mance Rayder’s hides were the shaggy white pelts of snow bears.

Jon I, ASOS

Jon Snow is the snow bear and the rightful King of the 7Ks. (It is known.lol)

In this tent is “a pregnant woman stood over a brazier cooking a brace of hens”.

“The good woman at the brazier,” Mance Rayder went on, “is Dalla.” The pregnant woman smiled shyly. “Treat her like you would any queen, she is carrying my child.”

So pregnant Lady Alyce Graceford, who appears to be a Sansa stand-in, from Sansa I, ASOS, and is married to one of the apple Fossoways, mirrors the shy Dalla, who is pregnant with a King’s child and ought to be treated like a queen in Jon I ASOS. Lady Graceford also sits on the left of King Joffrey, who is a Jon foil, in Tyrion VIII, ASOS, the place usually occupied by the queen.

I like this subtext very much.

Also, Mance Rayder’s physical description also has echoes of Jon’s physique in it.

“The King-beyond-the-Wall looked nothing like a king, nor even much a wildling. He was of middling height, slender, sharp-faced, with shrewd brown eyes and long brown hair that had gone mostly to grey. There was no crown on his head, no gold rings on his arms, no jewels at his throat, not even a gleam of silver. He wore wool and leather, and his only garment of note was his ragged black wool cloak, its long tears patched with faded red silk.”

-Jon I, ASOS

Jon is of middling height, slender and graceful and quick with eyes that hardly miss a thing. The black wool cloak patched with faded red silk is an obvious nod to the red and black colors of House Targaryen and thus to Jon. Hair gone mostly to grey is a node to the grey colors of House Stark. Again a nod to Jon, who is of the House Stark. The Black also denotes Jon and him being the black bastard of the Wall as part of the Night’s Watch. The “nor even much a wildling” may allude to Jon trying to infiltrate the wildlings and pretending to become a wildling in the process. However, he neither looks like one nor does he ends up becoming one.

Since all is subtext, I think this right here is actually meant to describe Jon and not Mance. The title of the King-beyond-the-Wall is such a clever way of calling Jon, the King, because if you think about it, when you are actually in the far North, past the Wall, and you are looking south, anything South of the Wall, can also be described as beyond the wall. And who is the rightful King of this side (Southern side) of the wall? Jon Snow of Houses Targaryen and Stark. 

Moving on, in this Jon I ASOS chapter, we first get to listen to the song The Dornishman’s Wife, and that is being sung by “a grey-haired man in a tattered cloak of black and red sat cross-legged on a pillow, playing a lute and singing..”

The grey-haired man in a cloak of black and red is another nod to Jon of the Houses Stark and Targaryen, who is also a Dornishman. A Dornishman’s wife can also be called a Dornishwoman. In fact, one of the only two times the word “Dornishwoman” shows up in the text in a POV chapter in ASOIAF, is in a Sansa chapter, Sansa IV, ASOS, talking about Ellaria Sand, paramour to the Red Viper of Dorne, Prince Oberyn. The other time is in the epilogue of ADWD.

Anyways, I think, there exists many subtextual clues that connect Jon and Sansa via apples or rather House Fossoway and may foreshadow them marrying and becoming King and Queen of the 7Ks and having a baby (or babies)!!! Here’s to at least some of that in S8!

(I am a quarter way through ASOS, and hopefully, if I can find any more apple connections, I will add on to this post. If others find some, would love to read about them. One thing that always strikes me is the sheer number of parallels that exist between Sansa I and Jon I chapters in ASOS, later chapters of these two also have quite a lot of clues).

I saw people posting about Sansa’s name and what it means on Tumblr yesterday and decided to post this bit about Sansa and apples and her connection to Jon. There could very well be more than one inspiration behind Sansa’s name but there exists a Sansa apple, which I have heard kind of tastes like Royal Gala apples, but I have never eaten one, so cannot tell (never seen one here in England either).

Plus it is apple-picking season, so why not!!!

Anyways, talking about apples, reminded me of this picture from that old Time magazine photo shoot that some of the GOT cast did a while back.

Here is Sophie Turner with a green apple (and she appears to have taken a bite off) in her hand and while others in the fandom have dissected the many meanings of this, here is what I found while I was re-reading A Storm of Swords. (if others have also talked about this, then oh well, another drop of water to the ocean and all that then) Part I will talk about Sansa’s connections to apples and Part II will feature Jon’s connections to apples. This post got longer than I planned.

There were three Tyrell cousins, Megga and Alla and Elinor, all close to Sansa’s age. Buxom Lady Janna was Lord Tyrell’s sister, and wed to one of the green-apple Fossoways; dainty, bright-eyed Lady Leonette was a Fossoway as well, and wed to Ser Garlan. Septa Nysterica had a homely pox-scarred face but seemed jolly. Pale, elegant Lady Graceford was with child, and Lady Bulwer was a child, no more than eight.

-Sansa I, ASOS

House Fossoway, sworn to House Tyrell, has two branches, the red apple Fossoways, and the green apple Fossoways. This Lady Janna is married to Ser Jon Fossoway, who is called Ser Jon of the green apple.

So Sansa is eating a green apple and there exists a Ser Jon of the green apple???!!! Are you kidding me!

In fact, this Ser Jon of the green apple first makes his appearance in a Sansa chapter!

“the freerider Lothor Brune, who’d cut his way through half a hundred Fossoway men-at-arms to capture Ser Jon of the green apple and kill Ser Bryan and Ser Edwyd of the red, thereby winning himself the name Lothor Apple-Eater.”

-Sansa VIII, ACOK

(This Lothor Brune is a free-rider, employed under Petyr Baelish and is connected to Sansa too. He once saved Sansa from the groping hands of Marillion, when she was in the Eyrie, that happens later in ASOS.)

Dainty and bright-eyed Lady Leonette is married to Ser Garlan Tyrell, who is called The Gallant and is a nod to Jon Snow. @shinynewrevulsions has written a meta on Jon Snow and Garlan Tyrell parallels.

Lady Leonette belongs to which branch of House Fossoway is unknown. So she could be a green apple Fossoway or a red apple Fossoway.

Pale and elegant Lady Graceford’s full name is Lady Alyce Graceford and she is pregnant. Alyce sounds like Alys, which reminds me of Alys Karstark, who is a Sansa stand-in. 

(Someone in the fandom wrote a meta on Sansa/Alys Karstark parallels, but I cannot find it. However, there is plenty of parallels between the two.)

Lady Graceford is described to be pale and elegant, words that are often used to describe Sansa.

This Lady Alyce Graceford shows up again later in ASOS…during Joffrey’s wedding. Tyrion and Sansa are sitting next to Ser Garlan Tyrell and Lady Leonette Fossoway at Joffrey’s wedding and Tyrion wonders this about Sansa…

“Does she wish it were her in Margaery’s place?” Tyrion frowned. Even a child should have better sense. He turned away, wanting distraction, but everywhere he looked were women, fair fine beautiful happy women who belonged to other men.”

-Tyrion VIII, ASOS

I think, “Everywhere he looked were women” also includes the woman sitting next to Tyrion, Sansa, who despite being married to him, belongs to someone else (IDK Jon??). 

“And there was one woman, sitting almost at the foot of the third table on the left…the wife of one of the Fossoways, he thought, and heavy with his child. Her delicate beauty was in no way diminished by her belly, nor was her pleasure in the food and frolics. Tyrion watched as her husband fed her morsels off his plate. They drank from the same cup, and would kiss often and unpredictably. Whenever they did, his hand would gently rest upon her stomach, a tender and protective gesture.”

-Tyrion VIII, ASOS

Sitting almost at the foot of the table reminds me of how Jon was made to sit at the lower benches in the Great Hall of Winterfell during the welcome feast for King Robert Baratheon. The third table may be alluding to Jon being the third child of Rhaegar. Sitting on the left side to Joffrey who is king and newly married so gets the highest seat of honor, also denotes the place where the queen resides. Joffrey is a foil to Jon. So this Lady sitting to Joffrey’s left denotes where Sansa might be sitting when she marries King Jon. (Tyrion and Sansa were sitting to Joffrey’s right)

blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: This idea that Tyrion would have loved to have sex with Sansa despite how utterly humiliated and ashamed and disgusted at...
body:
This idea that Tyrion would have loved to have sex with Sansa despite how utterly humiliated and ashamed and disgusted at himself and his body he feels when he’s around her in any kind of sexual context and this has nothing to do with him being a survivor of child sex abuse is so weird and gross and clueless.

Just because he says he “wants her” and he has an erection doesn’t mean that he wants any part of that situation, or that it isn’t traumatizing for him to be sexually coerced by the same person who coerced him as a child.

Like, good lord, y'all don’t even have much to do to read between the lines on this one.

He says he wants her, yeah, but he also characterizes those feelings as making him feel afraid (and knows it makes her afraid). This doesn’t exactly scream sexy times, Tyrion is literally saying “I am in a sexual situation I do not want and I am uncomfortable with how it’s making my body feel.” That’s sexual abuse, that’s rape, and it would be rape for both of them even if Tyrion doesn’t think of it that way because he’s been conditioned to accept Tywin’s bullshit.
